node.text:
“I just want a fair chance and a fair shot to compete at my highest level.”

US athlete Blake Leeper, a double amputee, is already a Paralympic silver medallist and world record holder - and now wants to compete in the Olympics.

But after the rules were changed in 2018, the blades that Leeper had been running on for years were deemed too long for competition.

Instead of shortening his blades, Blake took World Athletics to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, arguing their measuring system was not only “discriminatory”, but that he believed the Olympics was simply “not ready for a disabled man, not only to compete, but win".

He lost his case. Meanwhile, World Athletics strongly denies his allegation that the rules are discriminatory based on race.

#Olympics #BBCNews

node.title: Why was this athlete 'too tall' to race?

node.text:
“I wasn’t a very nice person.”

Football fan Neil, 56, says he was a racist and a bigot until his daughter Millie showed him that his behaviour was unacceptable.

He said he used to go along with racist chants at football matches, but is ashamed of his former behaviour and now describes himself as "anti-racist".

#Racism #BBCNews

node.title: 'I used to be a racist bigot'

node.text:
Taliban fighters entered Kabul airport within hours of the last US soldier leaving Afghanistan.

The militant group has been filmed celebrating on the tarmac with their leaders making a congratulatory speech.

Fighters were quick to investigate military equipment left behind, with some posing and taking pictures in aircraft.

#Afghanistan #Taliban #BBCNews

node.title: Taliban celebrate entering Kabul airport by posing in aircraft

node.text:
Female news anchor Beheshta Arghand made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, days after they took control of Afghanistan.

Two weeks later, she fled the country amid fears for her life.

"I'm so unhappy, because this generation really worked, really struggled for a new Afghanistan. I so miss my job, my country."

Tap the link in our bio for more stories from other Afghans forced to leave their homes - and their dreams behind.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.title: Female journalist who interviewed Taliban flees Afghanistan

node.text:
“Whether you have arms or not, sport has no limits.”

As taekwondo makes its debut at the Paralympic Games in Tokyo, two South Korean Para-athletes say that the sport has given them hope and energy.

#Tokyo2020 #Paralympics #Taekwondo #BBCNews

node.text:
Tens of thousands of people have been evacuated from the shores of Lake Tahoe in northern California as a major wildfire continues to spread.
 
More than 3,500 firefighters have been deployed to combat the Caldor Fire, which began more than two weeks ago, and has burned more than 191,000 acres.
 
The US Forest Service has also announced the closure of all Californian national forests until 17 September to stop the spread of wildfires.
 
Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the devestating fire.

#CaldorFire #California #LakeTahoe #BBCNews

node.text:
Across the world, women have been posting slogans on streets, walls and buildings to raise awareness of femicide and fight against everyday sexism.

The number of women in the UK killed or suspected of being killed by men in 2021 has reached 100, according to data collated by Counting Dead Women, a Femicide Census project.

The slogan campaign was started by a lone activist in Paris, and has spread in the UK too.

The women who go on pasting missions risk a fine if they're caught, but say it's a way for their voices to be heard.

#Feminism #Women #BBCNews

node.title: Tackling violence against women with slogan posters

node.text:
Major General Chris Donahue is the last American to board the final US military flight out of Afghanistan.

As the Taliban took over Kabul airport at the start of 31 August - the deadline President Biden had set for US withdrawal - shots were fired into the skies in celebration.

#Afghanistan #Taliban #BBCNews

node.title: The last US soldier leaves Afghanistan

node.text:
Louisiana residents may be in the dark for weeks as officials take stock of the damage from Hurricane Ida, which has been downgraded to a tropical storm.

Ida made landfall on Sunday with 150mph (240km/h) winds, the fifth strongest to ever hit the US mainland. 

About one million locals remain without power.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the impact of the storm.

#HurricaneIda #Louisiana #NewOrleans #Nola #BBCNews

node.title: Counting the cost after Hurricane Ida

A 20-storey block of flats in Milan, Italy was engulfed in flames on Sunday.

The apartment block is only 10 years old, and Milan Mayor Beppe Sala said it was "unacceptable that such a modern building should have proved totally vulnerable".

#Milan #Italy #Fire #BBCNews

node.title: Milan block of flats in flames

node.text:
The ancient art of pigeon fancying enjoyed a revival during the pandemic.

As restrictions eased in Turkey over the summer, enthusiasts have started to once again gather at Edirnekapı, Istanbul's largest pigeon market under the old Byzantine city walls.

#Animals #Pigeons #Turkey #BBCNews

node.title: Pigeon-keeping in Istanbul on the rise

node.text:
"Possum skin cloaks tell our story."

The Aboriginal cultural tradition of using possum skin cloaks to express identity was almost lost after colonisation - but it's now making a comeback.

#Australia #BBCNews

node.title: The revival of possum cloaks in Australia

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'NEWS Make-up artists fear for their lives and careers in Afghanistan a”istan'.

node.text:
As the Taliban moved across Afghanistan, beauty parlours and salons across the country were closed and covered in graffiti.

One make-up artist, ‘Afsoon’ (not her real name), woke up on the 15th of August to a call from her colleague saying “Don’t come in today. We are closing up. It's over.”

In the 1990s, before the US-led invasion to remove them from power, the Taliban banned all salons in the country because of their strict beliefs.

Now, as her scared friends paint over posters to appease the Taliban, Afsoon is stuck as she has no paperwork to get her out of the country.

As someone in the beauty industry, she says her work goes against the wishes of the new rules which say “that a woman must not attract attention.”

Tap the link in our bio to read more about what is being done to protect those left behind in Afghanistan.

(📷 Getty Images)

#Afghanistan #MakeUp #BBCNews

node.text:
The highest court in the United States has voted to allow a new Texas law banning most abortions to remain in place. 

The so-called Heartbeat Act bans terminations after cardiac activity is detected, which is at around six weeks - when many women don’t know they are pregnant.

The law came into effect on Wednesday, but rights groups asked for an injunction to prevent its enforcement. 

Unlike other abortion restrictions, the Texas law allows people to sue to enforce the law, even if they themselves have not been harmed. So an ordinary American could now seek up to $10,000 (£7,200) in damages in a civil court against abortion providers, doctors and even family members involved in the process.

US President Joe Biden has condemned the law, warning it would "significantly impair" women's access to healthcare.

Clink the link in our bio to find out more about what’s happening to abortion rights in the US.

#Texas #SCOTUS #BBCNews

node.text:
“I just want a fair chance and a fair shot to compete at my highest level.”

US athlete Blake Leeper, a double amputee, is already a Paralympic silver medallist and world record holder - and now wants to compete in the Olympics.

But after the rules were changed in 2018, the blades that Leeper had been running on for years were deemed too long for competition.

Instead of shortening his blades, Blake took World Athletics to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, arguing their measuring system was not only “discriminatory”, but that he believed the Olympics was simply “not ready for a disabled man, not only to compete, but win".

He lost his case. Meanwhile, World Athletics strongly denies his allegation that the rules are discriminatory based on race.

#Olympics #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BBC NEWS AM Sarah Storey is now Britain's most successful Paralympian of all time'.

node.text:
Sarah Storey clinched her 17th Paralympic gold on Thursday to become Great Britain's most successful Paralympian of all time.

The 43-year-old out-rode the competition in the women's C4-5 road race, putting her one gold ahead of previous record holder Mike Kenny.

"I'm a bit overwhelmed, I feel like it's happening to someone else," said the swimmer-turned-cyclist, who punched the air in celebration as she made it past the finish line.

"I can't really explain or compute anything about the race, but crossing the line first felt so good."

The athlete now has 28 Paralympic medals in total and has not won anything except gold since making her cycling Paralympic debut at Beijing 2008.

Tap the link in our bio for more on her record-breaking journey.

(📸: Getty Images)

#Tokyo2020 #Paralympics #BBCNews

Photo by BBC News in Delhi, India. May be an image of monument, sky and text that says 'BBNES NEWS Air pollution may reduce life expectancy of Indians by nine years, says study'.

node.text:
Research has found that 480 million people in northern India face the "most extreme levels of air pollution in the world”.

Indian cities routinely dominate global pollution rankings and bad air kills more than a million people every year.

The report by The Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago (EPIC) says that north India breathes "pollution levels that are 10 times worse than those found anywhere else in the world".

In Delhi, pictured, air pollution is especially bad in winters due to the burning of what is left on fields after harvesting.

Tap the link in our bio to see what can be done to reduce deadly air pollution across the world.

(📷 Getty Images)

#India #Environment #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 11 people and text that says 'BBNES NEWS 福 1 Û A 5 = 17 22 18 14 Football Association of Ireland announces equal pay for women's and men's teams'.

node.text:
"It's not about money, it's about being considered equal."

The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) said the "historic" move to pay both teams the same was made after talks including team captains Seamus Coleman and Katie McCabe.

Four years ago, the Republic of Ireland women's team threatened to go on strike in a protest over treatment by the FAI which led to a World Cup qualifier being in doubt.

However, relations between the women's squad and the football governing body have improved massively since then.

Tap the link in bio to read more about the move, which is being called "a great day for Irish football" by the captain Katie McCabe.

(📷 Getty Images)

#Football #ROI #BBCNews

node.text:
Taliban parade captured equipment in Kandahar.
 
The Taliban have paraded military equipment, captured during their takeover of Afghanistan, through the streets of Kandahar.
 
The militant showcase comes just days after US troops left Afghanistan, ending over two decades of military presence in the country.
 
#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BBC NEWS Will Smith reveals replacement in Fresh Prince of Bel-Air reboot'.

node.text:
Now this is a story all about how Jabari Banks’ life got flipped-turned upside down. And we'd like to take a minute, just sit right there, we'll tell you how Will Smith's successor got named the new Prince of Bel-Air.

The hit NBC show, which ran for six seasons from 1990 to 1996, helped launch Will to major success as both an actor and a rapper.

Jabari is from west Philadelphia ‘born and raised’, the same as Will’s character from the show, and is a singer-songwriter, rapper, and basketball player.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the reboot of the Fresh Prince.

(📷 Getty Images, NBC/ Peacock)

#FreshPrinceofBelAir #WillSmith #BBCNews

node.text:
“I wasn’t a very nice person.”

Football fan Neil, 56, says he was a racist and a bigot until his daughter Millie showed him that his behaviour was unacceptable.

He said he used to go along with racist chants at football matches, but is ashamed of his former behaviour and now describes himself as "anti-racist".

#Racism #BBCNews

node.text:
Taliban fighters entered Kabul airport within hours of the last US soldier leaving Afghanistan.

The militant group has been filmed celebrating on the tarmac with their leaders making a congratulatory speech.

Fighters were quick to investigate military equipment left behind, with some posing and taking pictures in aircraft.

#Afghanistan #Taliban #BBCNews

node.text:
Female news anchor Beheshta Arghand made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, days after they took control of Afghanistan.

Two weeks later, she fled the country amid fears for her life.

"I'm so unhappy, because this generation really worked, really struggled for a new Afghanistan. I so miss my job, my country."

Tap the link in our bio for more stories from other Afghans forced to leave their homes - and their dreams behind.

#Afghanistan #BBCNews

node.text:
“Whether you have arms or not, sport has no limits.”

As taekwondo makes its debut at the Paralympic Games in Tokyo, two South Korean Para-athletes say that the sport has given them hope and energy.

#Tokyo2020 #Paralympics #Taekwondo #BBCNews
